column2: Reply Obj. 5: The cogitative and memorative powers in man owe their excellence not to that which is proper to the sensitive part; but to a certain affinity and proximity to the universal reason, which, so to speak, overflows into them.
column3: Reply o b j. five: The cogitative and memorative powers in man owe their excellence not to that which is proper to the sensitive part; but to a certain affinity and proximity to the universal reason, which, so to speak, overflows into them.

column2: Therefore they are not distinct powers, but the same, yet more perfect than in other animals.
column3: Therefore they are not distinct powers, but the same, yet more perfect than in other animals.

column2: Reply Obj. 6: Augustine calls that vision spiritual which is effected by the images of bodies in the absence of bodies.
column3: Reply o b j. six: Augustine calls that vision spiritual which is effected by the images of bodies in the absence of bodies.

column2: Whence it is clear that it is common to all interior apprehensions. _______________________
column3: Whence it is clear that it is common to all interior apprehensions. , blank ,

column2: QUESTION 79
column3: QUESTION seventy nine

column2: OF THE INTELLECTUAL POWERS (In Thirteen Articles)
column3: OF THE INTELLECTUAL POWERS (In Thirteen Articles)

column2: The next question concerns the intellectual powers, under which head there are thirteen points of inquiry:
column3: The next question concerns the intellectual powers, under which head there are thirteen points of inquiry:

column2: (1) Whether the intellect is a power of the soul, or its essence?
column3: (one) Whether the intellect is a power of the soul, or its essence?

column2: (2) If it be a power, whether it is a passive power?
column3: (two) If it be a power, whether it is a passive power?

column2: (3) If it is a passive power, whether there is an active intellect?
column3: (three) If it is a passive power, whether there is an active intellect?

column2: (4) Whether it is something in the soul?
column3: (four) Whether it is something in the soul?

column2: (5) Whether the active intellect is one in all?
column3: (five) Whether the active intellect is one in all?

column2: (6) Whether memory is in the intellect?
column3: (six) Whether memory is in the intellect?

column2: (7) Whether the memory be distinct from the intellect?
column3: (seven) Whether the memory be distinct from the intellect?

column2: (8) Whether the reason is a distinct power from the intellect?
column3: (eight) Whether the reason is a distinct power from the intellect?

column2: (9) Whether the superior and inferior reason are distinct powers?
column3: (nine) Whether the superior and inferior reason are distinct powers?

column2: (10) Whether the intelligence is distinct from the intellect?
column3: (ten) Whether the intelligence is distinct from the intellect?

column2: (11) Whether the speculative and practical intellect are distinct powers?
column3: (eleven) Whether the speculative and practical intellect are distinct powers?

column2: (12) Whether "synderesis" is a power of the intellectual part?
column3: (twelve) Whether "synderesis" is a power of the intellectual part?

column2: (13) Whether the conscience is a power of the intellectual part? _______________________
column3: (thirteen) Whether the conscience is a power of the intellectual part? , blank ,

column2: FIRST ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art. 1]
column3: FIRST ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art. one]

column2: Whether the Intellect Is a Power of the Soul?
column3: Whether the Intellect Is a Power of the Soul?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the intellect is not a power of the soul, but the essence of the soul.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the intellect is not a power of the soul, but the essence of the soul.

column2: For the intellect seems to be the same as the mind.
column3: For the intellect seems to be the same as the mind.

column2: Now the mind is not a power of the soul, but the essence; for Augustine says (De Trin. ix, 2): "Mind and spirit are not relative things, but denominate the essence." Therefore the intellect is the essence of the soul.
column3: Now the mind is not a power of the soul, but the essence; for Augustine says (De Trin. ix, two): "Mind and spirit are not relative things, but denominate the essence." Therefore the intellect is the essence of the soul.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, different genera of the soul's powers are not united in some one power, but only in the essence of the soul.
column3: o b j. two: Further, different genera of the soul's powers are not united in some one power, but only in the essence of the soul.

column2: Now the appetitive and the intellectual are different genera of the soul's powers as the Philosopher says (De Anima ii, 3), but they are united in the mind, for Augustine (De Trin. x, 11) places the intelligence and will in the mind.
column3: Now the appetitive and the intellectual are different genera of the soul's powers as the Philosopher says (De Anima ii, three), but they are united in the mind, for Augustine (De Trin. x, eleven) places the intelligence and will in the mind.

column2: Therefore the mind and intellect of man is of the very essence of the soul and not a power thereof.
column3: Therefore the mind and intellect of man is of the very essence of the soul and not a power thereof.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, according to Gregory, in a homily for the Ascension (xxix in Ev.), "man understands with the angels." But angels are called "minds" and "intellects." Therefore the mind and intellect of man are not a power of the soul, but the soul itself.
column3: o b j. three: Further, according to Gregory, in a homily for the Ascension (x x i x in Ev.), "man understands with the angels." But angels are called "minds" and "intellects." Therefore the mind and intellect of man are not a power of the soul, but the soul itself.

column2: Obj. 4: Further, a substance is intellectual by the fact that it is immaterial.
column3: o b j. four: Further, a substance is intellectual by the fact that it is immaterial.

column2: But the soul is immaterial through its essence.
column3: But the soul is immaterial through its essence.

column2: Therefore it seems that the soul must be intellectual through its essence.
column3: Therefore it seems that the soul must be intellectual through its essence.

column2: _On the contrary,_ The Philosopher assigns the intellectual faculty as a power of the soul (De Anima ii, 3).
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore The Philosopher assigns the intellectual faculty as a power of the soul (De Anima ii, three).

column2: _I answer that,_ In accordance with what has been already shown (Q. 54, A. 3; Q. 77, A. 1) it is necessary to say that the intellect is a power of the soul, and not the very essence of the soul.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore In accordance with what has been already shown (Q. fifty four, a three; q seventy seven, a one) it is necessary to say that the intellect is a power of the soul, and not the very essence of the soul.

column2: For then alone the essence of that which operates is the immediate principle of operation, when operation itself is its being: for as power is to operation as its act, so is the essence to being.
column3: For then alone the essence of that which operates is the immediate principle of operation, when operation itself is its being: for as power is to operation as its act, so is the essence to being.

column2: But in God alone His action of understanding is His very Being.
column3: But in God alone His action of understanding is His very Being.

column2: Wherefore in God alone is His intellect His essence: while in other intellectual creatures, the intellect is a power.
column3: Wherefore in God alone is His intellect His essence: while in other intellectual creatures, the intellect is a power.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Sense is sometimes taken for the power, and sometimes for the sensitive soul; for the sensitive soul takes its name from its chief power, which is sense.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Sense is sometimes taken for the power, and sometimes for the sensitive soul; for the sensitive soul takes its name from its chief power, which is sense.

column2: And in like manner the intellectual soul is sometimes called intellect, as from its chief power; and thus we read (De Anima i, 4), that the "intellect is a substance." And in this sense also Augustine says that the mind is spirit and essence (De Trin. ix, 2; xiv, 16).
column3: And in like manner the intellectual soul is sometimes called intellect, as from its chief power; and thus we read (De Anima i, four), that the "intellect is a substance." And in this sense also Augustine says that the mind is spirit and essence (De Trin. ix, two; x i v, sixteen).

column2: Reply Obj. 2: The appetitive and intellectual powers are different genera of powers in the soul, by reason of the different formalities of their objects.
column3: Reply o b j. two: The appetitive and intellectual powers are different genera of powers in the soul, by reason of the different formalities of their objects.

column2: But the appetitive power agrees partly with the intellectual power and partly with the sensitive in its mode of operation either through a corporeal organ or without it: for appetite follows apprehension.
column3: But the appetitive power agrees partly with the intellectual power and partly with the sensitive in its mode of operation either through a corporeal organ or without it: for appetite follows apprehension.

column2: And in this way Augustine puts the will in the mind; and the Philosopher, in the reason (De Anima iii, 9).
column3: And in this way Augustine puts the will in the mind; and the Philosopher, in the reason (De Anima iii, nine).

column2: Reply Obj. 3: In the angels there is no other power besides the intellect, and the will, which follows the intellect.
column3: Reply o b j. three: In the angels there is no other power besides the intellect, and the will, which follows the intellect.

column2: And for this reason an angel is called a "mind" or an "intellect"; because his whole power consists in this.
column3: And for this reason an angel is called a "mind" or an "intellect"; because his whole power consists in this.

column2: But the soul has many other powers, such as the sensitive and nutritive powers, and therefore the comparison fails.
column3: But the soul has many other powers, such as the sensitive and nutritive powers, and therefore the comparison fails.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: The immateriality of the created intelligent substance is not its intellect; and through its immateriality it has the power of intelligence.
column3: Reply o b j. four: The immateriality of the created intelligent substance is not its intellect; and through its immateriality it has the power of intelligence.

column2: Wherefore it follows not that the intellect is the substance of the soul, but that it is its virtue and power. _______________________
column3: Wherefore it follows not that the intellect is the substance of the soul, but that it is its virtue and power. , blank ,

column2: SECOND ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art. 2]
column3: SECOND ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art. two]

column2: Whether the Intellect Is a Passive Power?
column3: Whether the Intellect Is a Passive Power?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the intellect is not a passive power. For everything is passive by its matter, and acts by its form.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the intellect is not a passive power. For everything is passive by its matter, and acts by its form.

column2: But the intellectual power results from the immateriality of the intelligent substance.
column3: But the intellectual power results from the immateriality of the intelligent substance.

column2: Therefore it seems that the intellect is not a passive power.
column3: Therefore it seems that the intellect is not a passive power.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, the intellectual power is incorruptible, as we have said above (Q. 79, A. 6).
column3: o b j. two: Further, the intellectual power is incorruptible, as we have said above (Q. seventy nine, a six).

column2: But "if the intellect is passive, it is corruptible" (De Anima iii, 5).
column3: But "if the intellect is passive, it is corruptible" (De Anima iii, five).

column2: Therefore the intellectual power is not passive.
column3: Therefore the intellectual power is not passive.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, the "agent is nobler than the patient," as Augustine (Gen. ad lit.
column3: o b j. three: Further, the "agent is nobler than the patient," as Augustine (Gen. ad lit.

column2: xii, 16) and Aristotle (De Anima iii, 5) says.
column3: x i i, sixteen) and Aristotle (De Anima iii, five) says.

column2: But all the powers of the vegetative part are active; yet they are the lowest among the powers of the soul.
column3: But all the powers of the vegetative part are active; yet they are the lowest among the powers of the soul.

column2: Much more, therefore, all the intellectual powers, which are the highest, are active.
column3: Much more, therefore, all the intellectual powers, which are the highest, are active.

column2: _On the contrary,_ The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 4) that "to understand is in a way to be passive."
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, four) that "to understand is in a way to be passive."

column2: _I answer that,_ To be passive may be taken in three ways.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore To be passive may be taken in three ways.

column2: Firstly, in its most strict sense, when from a thing is taken something which belongs to it by virtue either of its nature, or of its proper inclination: as when water loses coolness by heating, and as when a man becomes ill or sad.
column3: Firstly, in its most strict sense, when from a thing is taken something which belongs to it by virtue either of its nature, or of its proper inclination: as when water loses coolness by heating, and as when a man becomes ill or sad.

column2: Secondly, less strictly, a thing is said to be passive, when something, whether suitable or unsuitable, is taken away from it.
column3: Secondly, less strictly, a thing is said to be passive, when something, whether suitable or unsuitable, is taken away from it.

column2: And in this way not only he who is ill is said to be passive, but also he who is healed; not only he that is sad, but also he that is joyful; or whatever way he be altered or moved.
column3: And in this way not only he who is ill is said to be passive, but also he who is healed; not only he that is sad, but also he that is joyful; or whatever way he be altered or moved.

column2: Thirdly, in a wide sense a thing is said to be passive, from the very fact that what is in potentiality to something receives that to which it was in potentiality, without being deprived of anything.
column3: Thirdly, in a wide sense a thing is said to be passive, from the very fact that what is in potentiality to something receives that to which it was in potentiality, without being deprived of anything.

column2: And accordingly, whatever passes from potentiality to act, may be said to be passive, even when it is perfected.
column3: And accordingly, whatever passes from potentiality to act, may be said to be passive, even when it is perfected.

column2: And thus with us to understand is to be passive.
column3: And thus with us to understand is to be passive.

column2: This is clear from the following reason.
column3: This is clear from the following reason.

column2: For the intellect, as we have seen above (Q. 78, A. 1), has an operation extending to universal being.
column3: For the intellect, as we have seen above (Q. seventy eight, a one), has an operation extending to universal being.

column2: We may therefore see whether the intellect be in act or potentiality by observing first of all the nature of the relation of the intellect to universal being.
column3: We may therefore see whether the intellect be in act or potentiality by observing first of all the nature of the relation of the intellect to universal being.

column2: For we find an intellect whose relation to universal being is that of the act of all being: and such is the Divine intellect, which is the Essence of God, in which originally and virtually, all being pre-exists as in its first cause.
column3: For we find an intellect whose relation to universal being is that of the act of all being: and such is the Divine intellect, which is the Essence of God, in which originally and virtually, all being pre exists as in its first cause.

column2: And therefore the Divine intellect is not in potentiality, but is pure act.
column3: And therefore the Divine intellect is not in potentiality, but is pure act.

column2: But no created intellect can be an act in relation to the whole universal being; otherwise it would needs be an infinite being.
column3: But no created intellect can be an act in relation to the whole universal being; otherwise it would needs be an infinite being.

column2: Wherefore every created intellect is not the act of all things intelligible, by reason of its very existence; but is compared to these intelligible things as a potentiality to act.
column3: Wherefore every created intellect is not the act of all things intelligible, by reason of its very existence; but is compared to these intelligible things as a potentiality to act.

column2: Now, potentiality has a double relation to act.
column3: Now, potentiality has a double relation to act.

column2: There is a potentiality which is always perfected by its act: as the matter of the heavenly bodies (Q.
column3: There is a potentiality which is always perfected by its act: as the matter of the heavenly bodies (Q.
fifty eight, a one).

column2: And there is another potentiality which is not always in act, but proceeds from potentiality to act; as we observe in things that are corrupted and generated.
column3: And there is another potentiality which is not always in act, but proceeds from potentiality to act; as we observe in things that are corrupted and generated.

column2: Wherefore the angelic intellect is always in act as regards those things which it can understand, by reason of its proximity to the first intellect, which is pure act, as we have said above.
column3: Wherefore the angelic intellect is always in act as regards those things which it can understand, by reason of its proximity to the first intellect, which is pure act, as we have said above.

column2: But the human intellect, which is the lowest in the order of intelligence and most remote from the perfection of the Divine intellect, is in potentiality with regard to things intelligible, and is at first "like a clean tablet on which nothing is written," as the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 4).
column3: But the human intellect, which is the lowest in the order of intelligence and most remote from the perfection of the Divine intellect, is in potentiality with regard to things intelligible, and is at first "like a clean tablet on which nothing is written," as the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, four).

column2: This is made clear from the fact, that at first we are only in potentiality to understand, and afterwards we are made to understand actually.
column3: This is made clear from the fact, that at first we are only in potentiality to understand, and afterwards we are made to understand actually.

column2: And so it is evident that with us to understand is "in a way to be passive"; taking passion in the third sense.
column3: And so it is evident that with us to understand is "in a way to be passive"; taking passion in the third sense.

column2: And consequently the intellect is a passive power.
column3: And consequently the intellect is a passive power.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: This objection is verified of passion in the first and second senses, which belong to primary matter.
column3: Reply o b j. one: This objection is verified of passion in the first and second senses, which belong to primary matter.

column2: But in the third sense passion is in anything which is reduced from potentiality to act.
column3: But in the third sense passion is in anything which is reduced from potentiality to act.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: "Passive intellect" is the name given by some to the sensitive appetite, in which are the passions of the soul; which appetite is also called "rational by participation," because it "obeys the reason" (Ethic.
column3: Reply o b j. two: "Passive intellect" is the name given by some to the sensitive appetite, in which are the passions of the soul; which appetite is also called "rational by participation," because it "obeys the reason" (Ethic.
i, thirteen).

column2: Others give the name of passive intellect to the cogitative power, which is called the "particular reason." And in each case "passive" may be taken in the two first senses; forasmuch as this so-called intellect is the act of a corporeal organ.
column3: Others give the name of passive intellect to the cogitative power, which is called the "particular reason." And in each case "passive" may be taken in the two first senses; forasmuch as this so-called intellect is the act of a corporeal organ.

column2: But the intellect which is in potentiality to things intelligible, and which for this reason Aristotle calls the "possible" intellect (De Anima iii, 4) is not passive except in the third sense: for it is not an act of a corporeal organ.
column3: But the intellect which is in potentiality to things intelligible, and which for this reason Aristotle calls the "possible" intellect (De Anima iii, four) is not passive except in the third sense: for it is not an act of a corporeal organ.

column2: Hence it is incorruptible.
column3: Hence it is incorruptible.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: The agent is nobler than the patient, if the action and the passion are referred to the same thing: but not always, if they refer to different things.
column3: Reply o b j. three: The agent is nobler than the patient, if the action and the passion are referred to the same thing: but not always, if they refer to different things.

column2: Now the intellect is a passive power in regard to the whole universal being: while the vegetative power is active in regard to some particular thing, namely, the body as united to the soul.
column3: Now the intellect is a passive power in regard to the whole universal being: while the vegetative power is active in regard to some particular thing, namely, the body as united to the soul.

column2: Wherefore nothing prevents such a passive force being nobler than such an active one. _______________________
column3: Wherefore nothing prevents such a passive force being nobler than such an active one. , blank ,

column2: THIRD ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art. 3]
column3: THIRD ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art. three]

column2: Whether There Is an Active Intellect?
column3: Whether There Is an Active Intellect?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that there is no active intellect.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that there is no active intellect.

column2: For as the senses are to things sensible, so is our intellect to things intelligible.
column3: For as the senses are to things sensible, so is our intellect to things intelligible.

column2: But because sense is in potentiality to things sensible, the sense is not said to be active, but only passive.
column3: But because sense is in potentiality to things sensible, the sense is not said to be active, but only passive.

column2: Therefore, since our intellect is in potentiality to things intelligible, it seems that we cannot say that the intellect is active, but only that it is passive.
column3: Therefore, since our intellect is in potentiality to things intelligible, it seems that we cannot say that the intellect is active, but only that it is passive.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, if we say that also in the senses there is something active, such as light: on the contrary, light is required for sight, inasmuch as it makes the medium to be actually luminous; for color of its own nature moves the luminous medium.
column3: o b j. two: Further, if we say that also in the senses there is something active, such as light: on the contrary, light is required for sight, inasmuch as it makes the medium to be actually luminous; for color of its own nature moves the luminous medium.

column2: But in the operation of the intellect there is no appointed medium that has to be brought into act.
column3: But in the operation of the intellect there is no appointed medium that has to be brought into act.

column2: Therefore there is no necessity for an active intellect.
column3: Therefore there is no necessity for an active intellect.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, the likeness of the agent is received into the patient according to the nature of the patient.
column3: o b j. three: Further, the likeness of the agent is received into the patient according to the nature of the patient.

column2: But the passive intellect is an immaterial power.
column3: But the passive intellect is an immaterial power.

column2: Therefore its immaterial nature suffices for forms to be received into it immaterially.
column3: Therefore its immaterial nature suffices for forms to be received into it immaterially.

column2: Now a form is intelligible in act from the very fact that it is immaterial. Therefore there is no need for an active intellect to make the species actually intelligible.
column3: Now a form is intelligible in act from the very fact that it is immaterial. Therefore there is no need for an active intellect to make the species actually intelligible.

column2: _On the contrary,_ The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 5), "As in every nature, so in the soul is there something by which it becomes all things, and something by which it makes all things." Therefore we must admit an active intellect.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, five), "As in every nature, so in the soul is there something by which it becomes all things, and something by which it makes all things." Therefore we must admit an active intellect.

column2: _I answer that,_ According to the opinion of Plato, there is no need for an active intellect in order to make things actually intelligible; but perhaps in order to provide intellectual light to the intellect, as will be explained farther on (A. 4).
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore According to the opinion of Plato, there is no need for an active intellect in order to make things actually intelligible; but perhaps in order to provide intellectual light to the intellect, as will be explained farther on (A. four).

column2: For Plato supposed that the forms of natural things subsisted apart from matter, and consequently that they are intelligible: since a thing is actually intelligible from the very fact that it is immaterial.
column3: For Plato supposed that the forms of natural things subsisted apart from matter, and consequently that they are intelligible: since a thing is actually intelligible from the very fact that it is immaterial.

column2: And he called such forms "species or ideas"; from a participation of which, he said that even corporeal matter was formed, in order that individuals might be naturally established in their proper genera and species: and that our intellect was formed by such participation in order to have knowledge of the genera and species of things.
column3: And he called such forms "species or ideas"; from a participation of which, he said that even corporeal matter was formed, in order that individuals might be naturally established in their proper genera and species: and that our intellect was formed by such participation in order to have knowledge of the genera and species of things.

column2: But since Aristotle did not allow that forms of natural things exist apart from matter, and as forms existing in matter are not actually intelligible; it follows that the natures or forms of the sensible things which we understand are not actually intelligible.
column3: But since Aristotle did not allow that forms of natural things exist apart from matter, and as forms existing in matter are not actually intelligible; it follows that the natures or forms of the sensible things which we understand are not actually intelligible.

column2: Now nothing is reduced from potentiality to act except by something in act; as the senses as made actual by what is actually sensible.
column3: Now nothing is reduced from potentiality to act except by something in act; as the senses as made actual by what is actually sensible.

column2: We must therefore assign on the part of the intellect some power to make things actually intelligible, by abstraction of the species from material conditions.
column3: We must therefore assign on the part of the intellect some power to make things actually intelligible, by abstraction of the species from material conditions.

column2: And such is the necessity for an active intellect.
column3: And such is the necessity for an active intellect.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Sensible things are found in act outside the soul; and hence there is no need for an active sense.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Sensible things are found in act outside the soul; and hence there is no need for an active sense.

column2: Wherefore it is clear that in the nutritive part all the powers are active, whereas in the sensitive part all are passive: but in the intellectual part, there is something active and something passive.
column3: Wherefore it is clear that in the nutritive part all the powers are active, whereas in the sensitive part all are passive: but in the intellectual part, there is something active and something passive.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: There are two opinions as to the effect of light.
column3: Reply o b j. two: There are two opinions as to the effect of light.

column2: For some say that light is required for sight, in order to make colors actually visible.
column3: For some say that light is required for sight, in order to make colors actually visible.

column2: And according to this the active intellect is required for understanding, in like manner and for the same reason as light is required for seeing.
column3: And according to this the active intellect is required for understanding, in like manner and for the same reason as light is required for seeing.

column2: But in the opinion of others, light is required for sight; not for the colors to become actually visible; but in order that the medium may become actually luminous, as the Commentator says on _De Anima_ ii.
column3: But in the opinion of others, light is required for sight; not for the colors to become actually visible; but in order that the medium may become actually luminous, as the Commentator says on underscore De Anima underscore ii.

column2: And according to this, Aristotle's comparison of the active intellect to light is verified in this, that as it is required for understanding, so is light required for seeing; but not for the same reason.
column3: And according to this, Aristotle's comparison of the active intellect to light is verified in this, that as it is required for understanding, so is light required for seeing; but not for the same reason.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: If the agent pre-exist, it may well happen that its likeness is received variously into various things, on account of their dispositions.
column3: Reply o b j. three: If the agent pre exist, it may well happen that its likeness is received variously into various things, on account of their dispositions.

column2: But if the agent does not pre-exist, the disposition of the recipient has nothing to do with the matter.
column3: But if the agent does not pre exist, the disposition of the recipient has nothing to do with the matter.

column2: Now the intelligible in act is not something existing in nature; if we consider the nature of things sensible, which do not subsist apart from matter.
column3: Now the intelligible in act is not something existing in nature; if we consider the nature of things sensible, which do not subsist apart from matter.

column2: And therefore in order to understand them, the immaterial nature of the passive intellect would not suffice but for the presence of the active intellect which makes things actually intelligible by way of abstraction. _______________________
column3: And therefore in order to understand them, the immaterial nature of the passive intellect would not suffice but for the presence of the active intellect which makes things actually intelligible by way of abstraction. , blank ,

column2: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art. 4]
column3: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art. four]

column2: Whether the Active Intellect Is Something in the Soul?
column3: Whether the Active Intellect Is Something in the Soul?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the active intellect is not something in the soul.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the active intellect is not something in the soul.

column2: For the effect of the active intellect is to give light for the purpose of understanding.
column3: For the effect of the active intellect is to give light for the purpose of understanding.

column2: But this is done by something higher than the soul: according to John 1:9, "He was the true light that enlighteneth every man coming into this world." Therefore the active intellect is not something in the soul.
column3: But this is done by something higher than the soul: according to john chapter one verse nine, "He was the true light that enlighteneth every man coming into this world." Therefore the active intellect is not something in the soul.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, the Philosopher (De Anima iii, 5) says of the active intellect, "that it does not sometimes understand and sometimes not understand." But our soul does not always understand: sometimes it understands, sometimes it does not understand.
column3: o b j. two: Further, the Philosopher (De Anima iii, five) says of the active intellect, "that it does not sometimes understand and sometimes not understand." But our soul does not always understand: sometimes it understands, sometimes it does not understand.

column2: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.
column3: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, agent and patient suffice for action.
column3: o b j. three: Further, agent and patient suffice for action.

column2: If, therefore, the passive intellect, which is a passive power, is something belonging to the soul; and also the active intellect, which is an active power: it follows that a man would always be able to understand when he wished, which is clearly false.
column3: If, therefore, the passive intellect, which is a passive power, is something belonging to the soul; and also the active intellect, which is an active power: it follows that a man would always be able to understand when he wished, which is clearly false.

column2: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.
column3: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.

column2: Obj. 4: Further, the Philosopher (De Anima iii, 5) says that the active intellect is a "substance in actual being." But nothing can be in potentiality and in act with regard to the same thing.
column3: o b j. four: Further, the Philosopher (De Anima iii, five) says that the active intellect is a "substance in actual being." But nothing can be in potentiality and in act with regard to the same thing.

column2: If, therefore, the passive intellect, which is in potentiality to all things intelligible, is something in the soul, it seems impossible for the active intellect to be also something in our soul.
column3: If, therefore, the passive intellect, which is in potentiality to all things intelligible, is something in the soul, it seems impossible for the active intellect to be also something in our soul.

column2: Obj. 5: Further, if the active intellect is something in the soul, it must be a power.
column3: o b j. five: Further, if the active intellect is something in the soul, it must be a power.

column2: For it is neither a passion nor a habit; since habits and passions are not in the nature of agents in regard to the passivity of the soul; but rather passion is the very action of the passive power; while habit is something which results from acts.
column3: For it is neither a passion nor a habit; since habits and passions are not in the nature of agents in regard to the passivity of the soul; but rather passion is the very action of the passive power; while habit is something which results from acts.

column2: But every power flows from the essence of the soul.
column3: But every power flows from the essence of the soul.

column2: It would therefore follow that the active intellect flows from the essence of the soul. And thus it would not be in the soul by way of participation from some higher intellect: which is unfitting.
column3: It would therefore follow that the active intellect flows from the essence of the soul. And thus it would not be in the soul by way of participation from some higher intellect: which is unfitting.

column2: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.
column3: Therefore the active intellect is not something in our soul.

column2: _On the contrary,_ The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 5), that "it is necessary for these differences," namely, the passive and active intellect, "to be in the soul."
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, five), that "it is necessary for these differences," namely, the passive and active intellect, "to be in the soul."

column2: _I answer that,_ The active intellect, of which the Philosopher speaks, is something in the soul.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore The active intellect, of which the Philosopher speaks, is something in the soul.

column2: In order to make this evident, we must observe that above the intellectual soul of man we must needs suppose a superior intellect, from which the soul acquires the power of understanding.
column3: In order to make this evident, we must observe that above the intellectual soul of man we must needs suppose a superior intellect, from which the soul acquires the power of understanding.

column2: For what is such by participation, and what is mobile, and what is imperfect always requires the pre-existence of something essentially such, immovable and perfect.
column3: For what is such by participation, and what is mobile, and what is imperfect always requires the pre existence of something essentially such, immovable and perfect.

column2: Now the human soul is called intellectual by reason of a participation in intellectual power; a sign of which is that it is not wholly intellectual but only in part.
column3: Now the human soul is called intellectual by reason of a participation in intellectual power; a sign of which is that it is not wholly intellectual but only in part.

column2: Moreover it reaches to the understanding of truth by arguing, with a certain amount of reasoning and movement.
column3: Moreover it reaches to the understanding of truth by arguing, with a certain amount of reasoning and movement.

column2: Again it has an imperfect understanding; both because it does not understand everything, and because, in those things which it does understand, it passes from potentiality to act.
column3: Again it has an imperfect understanding; both because it does not understand everything, and because, in those things which it does understand, it passes from potentiality to act.

column2: Therefore there must needs be some higher intellect, by which the soul is helped to understand.
column3: Therefore there must needs be some higher intellect, by which the soul is helped to understand.

column2: Wherefore some held that this intellect, substantially separate, is the active intellect, which by lighting up the phantasms as it were, makes them to be actually intelligible.
column3: Wherefore some held that this intellect, substantially separate, is the active intellect, which by lighting up the phantasms as it were, makes them to be actually intelligible.

column2: But, even supposing the existence of such a separate active intellect, it would still be necessary to assign to the human soul some power participating in that superior intellect, by which power the human soul makes things actually intelligible.
column3: But, even supposing the existence of such a separate active intellect, it would still be necessary to assign to the human soul some power participating in that superior intellect, by which power the human soul makes things actually intelligible.

column2: Just as in other perfect natural things, besides the universal active causes, each one is endowed with its proper powers derived from those universal causes: for the sun alone does not generate man; but in man is the power of begetting man: and in like manner with other perfect animals.
column3: Just as in other perfect natural things, besides the universal active causes, each one is endowed with its proper powers derived from those universal causes: for the sun alone does not generate man; but in man is the power of begetting man: and in like manner with other perfect animals.

column2: Now among these lower things nothing is more perfect than the human soul.
column3: Now among these lower things nothing is more perfect than the human soul.

column2: Wherefore we must say that in the soul is some power derived from a higher intellect, whereby it is able to light up the phantasms.
column3: Wherefore we must say that in the soul is some power derived from a higher intellect, whereby it is able to light up the phantasms.

column2: And we know this by experience, since we perceive that we abstract universal forms from their particular conditions, which is to make them actually intelligible.
column3: And we know this by experience, since we perceive that we abstract universal forms from their particular conditions, which is to make them actually intelligible.

column2: Now no action belongs to anything except through some principle formally inherent therein; as we have said above of the passive intellect (Q. 76, A. 1).
column3: Now no action belongs to anything except through some principle formally inherent therein; as we have said above of the passive intellect (Q. seventy six, a one).

column2: Therefore the power which is the principle of this action must be something in the soul.
column3: Therefore the power which is the principle of this action must be something in the soul.

column2: For this reason Aristotle (De Anima iii, 5) compared the active intellect to light, which is something received into the air: while Plato compared the separate intellect impressing the soul to the sun, as Themistius says in his commentary on _De Anima_ iii.
column3: For this reason Aristotle (De Anima iii, five) compared the active intellect to light, which is something received into the air: while Plato compared the separate intellect impressing the soul to the sun, as Themistius says in his commentary on underscore De Anima underscore iii.

column2: But the separate intellect, according to the teaching of our faith, is God Himself, Who is the soul's Creator, and only beatitude; as will be shown later on (Q. 90, A. 3; I-II, Q. 3, A. 7).
column3: But the separate intellect, according to the teaching of our faith, is God Himself, Who is the soul's Creator, and only beatitude; as will be shown later on (Q. ninety, a three; I two, q three, a seven).

column2: Wherefore the human soul derives its intellectual light from Him, according to Ps. 4:7, "The light of Thy countenance, O Lord, is signed upon us."
column3: Wherefore the human soul derives its intellectual light from Him, according to p's. four to seven, "The light of Thy countenance, O Lord, is signed upon us."

column2: Reply Obj. 1: That true light enlightens as a universal cause, from which the human soul derives a particular power, as we have explained.
column3: Reply o b j. one: That true light enlightens as a universal cause, from which the human soul derives a particular power, as we have explained.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: The Philosopher says those words not of the active intellect, but of the intellect in act: of which he had already said: "Knowledge in act is the same as the thing." Or, if we refer those words to the active intellect, then they are said because it is not owing to the active intellect that sometimes we do, and sometimes we do not understand, but to the intellect which is in potentiality.
column3: Reply o b j. two: The Philosopher says those words not of the active intellect, but of the intellect in act: of which he had already said: "Knowledge in act is the same as the thing." Or, if we refer those words to the active intellect, then they are said because it is not owing to the active intellect that sometimes we do, and sometimes we do not understand, but to the intellect which is in potentiality.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: If the relation of the active intellect to the passive were that of the active object to a power, as, for instance, of the visible in act to the sight; it would follow that we could understand all things instantly, since the active intellect is that which makes all things (in act).
column3: Reply o b j. three: If the relation of the active intellect to the passive were that of the active object to a power, as, for instance, of the visible in act to the sight; it would follow that we could understand all things instantly, since the active intellect is that which makes all things (in act).

column2: But now the active intellect is not an object, rather is it that whereby the objects are made to be in act: for which, besides the presence of the active intellect, we require the presence of phantasms, the good disposition of the sensitive powers, and practice in this sort of operation; since through one thing understood, other things come to be understood, as from terms are made propositions, and from first principles, conclusions.
column3: But now the active intellect is not an object, rather is it that whereby the objects are made to be in act: for which, besides the presence of the active intellect, we require the presence of phantasms, the good disposition of the sensitive powers, and practice in this sort of operation; since through one thing understood, other things come to be understood, as from terms are made propositions, and from first principles, conclusions.

column2: From this point of view it matters not whether the active intellect is something belonging to the soul, or something separate from the soul.
column3: From this point of view it matters not whether the active intellect is something belonging to the soul, or something separate from the soul.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: The intellectual soul is indeed actually immaterial, but it is in potentiality to determinate species.
column3: Reply o b j. four: The intellectual soul is indeed actually immaterial, but it is in potentiality to determinate species.

column2: On the contrary, phantasms are actual images of certain species, but are immaterial in potentiality.
column3: On the contrary, phantasms are actual images of certain species, but are immaterial in potentiality.

column2: Wherefore nothing prevents one and the same soul, inasmuch as it is actually immaterial, having one power by which it makes things actually immaterial, by abstraction from the conditions of individual matter: which power is called the "active intellect"; and another power, receptive of such species, which is called the "passive intellect" by reason of its being in potentiality to such species.
column3: Wherefore nothing prevents one and the same soul, inasmuch as it is actually immaterial, having one power by which it makes things actually immaterial, by abstraction from the conditions of individual matter: which power is called the "active intellect"; and another power, receptive of such species, which is called the "passive intellect" by reason of its being in potentiality to such species.

column2: Reply Obj. 5: Since the essence of the soul is immaterial, created by the supreme intellect, nothing prevents that power which it derives from the supreme intellect, and whereby it abstracts from matter, flowing from the essence of the soul, in the same way as its other powers. _______________________
column3: Reply o b j. five: Since the essence of the soul is immaterial, created by the supreme intellect, nothing prevents that power which it derives from the supreme intellect, and whereby it abstracts from matter, flowing from the essence of the soul, in the same way as its other powers. , blank ,

column2: FIFTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art.
column3: FIFTH ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art.
five]

column2: Whether the Active Intellect Is One in All?
column3: Whether the Active Intellect Is One in All?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that there is one active intellect in all. For what is separate from the body is not multiplied according to the number of bodies.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that there is one active intellect in all. For what is separate from the body is not multiplied according to the number of bodies.

column2: But the active intellect is "separate," as the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 5).
column3: But the active intellect is "separate," as the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, five).

column2: Therefore it is not multiplied in the many human bodies, but is one for all men.
column3: Therefore it is not multiplied in the many human bodies, but is one for all men.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, the active intellect is the cause of the universal, which is one in many.
column3: o b j. two: Further, the active intellect is the cause of the universal, which is one in many.

column2: But that which is the cause of unity is still more itself one.
column3: But that which is the cause of unity is still more itself one.

column2: Therefore the active intellect is the same in all.
column3: Therefore the active intellect is the same in all.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, all men agree in the first intellectual concepts. But to these they assent by the active intellect.
column3: o b j. three: Further, all men agree in the first intellectual concepts. But to these they assent by the active intellect.

column2: Therefore all agree in one active intellect.
column3: Therefore all agree in one active intellect.

column2: _On the contrary,_ The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 5) that the active intellect is as a light.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore The Philosopher says (De Anima iii, five) that the active intellect is as a light.

column2: But light is not the same in the various things enlightened.
column3: But light is not the same in the various things enlightened.

column2: Therefore the same active intellect is not in various men.
column3: Therefore the same active intellect is not in various men.

column2: _I answer that,_ The truth about this question depends on what we have already said (A. 4).
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore The truth about this question depends on what we have already said (A. four).

column2: For if the active intellect were not something belonging to the soul, but were some separate substance, there would be one active intellect for all men.
column3: For if the active intellect were not something belonging to the soul, but were some separate substance, there would be one active intellect for all men.

column2: And this is what they mean who hold that there is one active intellect for all.
column3: And this is what they mean who hold that there is one active intellect for all.

column2: But if the active intellect is something belonging to the soul, as one of its powers, we are bound to say that there are as many active intellects as there are souls, which are multiplied according to the number of men, as we have said above (Q. 76, A. 2).
column3: But if the active intellect is something belonging to the soul, as one of its powers, we are bound to say that there are as many active intellects as there are souls, which are multiplied according to the number of men, as we have said above (Q. seventy six, a two).

column2: For it is impossible that one same power belong to various substances.
column3: For it is impossible that one same power belong to various substances.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: The Philosopher proves that the active intellect is separate, by the fact that the passive intellect is separate: because, as he says (De Anima iii, 5), "the agent is more noble than the patient." Now the passive intellect is said to be separate, because it is not the act of any corporeal organ.
column3: Reply o b j. one: The Philosopher proves that the active intellect is separate, by the fact that the passive intellect is separate: because, as he says (De Anima iii, five), "the agent is more noble than the patient." Now the passive intellect is said to be separate, because it is not the act of any corporeal organ.

column2: And in the same sense the active intellect is also called "separate"; but not as a separate substance.
column3: And in the same sense the active intellect is also called "separate"; but not as a separate substance.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: The active intellect is the cause of the universal, by abstracting it from matter.
column3: Reply o b j. two: The active intellect is the cause of the universal, by abstracting it from matter.

column2: But for this purpose it need not be the same intellect in all intelligent beings; but it must be one in its relationship to all those things from which it abstracts the universal, with respect to which things the universal is one.
column3: But for this purpose it need not be the same intellect in all intelligent beings; but it must be one in its relationship to all those things from which it abstracts the universal, with respect to which things the universal is one.

column2: And this befits the active intellect inasmuch as it is immaterial.
column3: And this befits the active intellect inasmuch as it is immaterial.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: All things which are of one species enjoy in common the action which accompanies the nature of the species, and consequently the power which is the principle of such action; but not so as that power be identical in all.
column3: Reply o b j. three: All things which are of one species enjoy in common the action which accompanies the nature of the species, and consequently the power which is the principle of such action; but not so as that power be identical in all.

column2: Now to know the first intelligible principles is the action belonging to the human species.
column3: Now to know the first intelligible principles is the action belonging to the human species.

column2: Wherefore all men enjoy in common the power which is the principle of this action: and this power is the active intellect.
column3: Wherefore all men enjoy in common the power which is the principle of this action: and this power is the active intellect.

column2: But there is no need for it to be identical in all.
column3: But there is no need for it to be identical in all.

column2: Yet it must be derived by all from one principle.
column3: Yet it must be derived by all from one principle.

column2: And thus the possession by all men in common of the first principles proves the unity of the separate intellect, which Plato compares to the sun; but not the unity of the active intellect, which Aristotle compares to light. _______________________
column3: And thus the possession by all men in common of the first principles proves the unity of the separate intellect, which Plato compares to the sun; but not the unity of the active intellect, which Aristotle compares to light. , blank ,

column2: SIXTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 79, Art.
column3: SIXTH ARTICLE [I, q seventy nine, Art.
six]

column2: Whether Memory Is in the Intellectual Part of the Soul?
column3: Whether Memory Is in the Intellectual Part of the Soul?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that memory is not in the intellectual part of the soul.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that memory is not in the intellectual part of the soul.

column2: For Augustine says (De Trin.
column3: For Augustine says (De Trin.

column2: xii, 2,3,8) that to the higher part of the soul belongs those things which are not "common to man and beast." But memory is common to man and beast, for he says (De Trin. xii, 2, 3, 8) that "beasts can sense corporeal things through the senses of the body, and commit them to memory." Therefore memory does not belong to the intellectual part of the soul.
column3: x i i, two,three,eight) that to the higher part of the soul belongs those things which are not "common to man and beast." But memory is common to man and beast, for he says (De Trin. x i i, two, three, eight) that "beasts can sense corporeal things through the senses of the body, and commit them to memory." Therefore memory does not belong to the intellectual part of the soul.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, memory is of the past.
column3: o b j. two: Further, memory is of the past.

column2: But the past is said of something with regard to a fixed time.
column3: But the past is said of something with regard to a fixed time.

column2: Memory, therefore, knows a thing under a condition of a fixed time; which involves knowledge under the conditions of "here" and "now." But this is not the province of the intellect, but of the sense.
column3: Memory, therefore, knows a thing under a condition of a fixed time; which involves knowledge under the conditions of "here" and "now." But this is not the province of the intellect, but of the sense.

column2: Therefore memory is not in the intellectual part, but only in the sensitive.
column3: Therefore memory is not in the intellectual part, but only in the sensitive.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, in the memory are preserved the species of those things of which we are not actually thinking.
column3: o b j. three: Further, in the memory are preserved the species of those things of which we are not actually thinking.

column2: But this cannot happen in the intellect, because the intellect is reduced to act by the fact that the intelligible species are received into it.
column3: But this cannot happen in the intellect, because the intellect is reduced to act by the fact that the intelligible species are received into it.

column2: Now the intellect in act implies understanding in act; and therefore the intellect actually understands all things of which it has the species. Therefore the memory is not in the intellectual part.
column3: Now the intellect in act implies understanding in act; and therefore the intellect actually understands all things of which it has the species. Therefore the memory is not in the intellectual part.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Augustine says (De Trin. x, 11) that "memory, understanding, and will are one mind."
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Augustine says (De Trin. x, eleven) that "memory, understanding, and will are one mind."

column2: _I answer that,_ Since it is of the nature of the memory to preserve the species of those things which are not actually apprehended, we must first of all consider whether the intelligible species can thus be preserved in the intellect: because Avicenna held that this was impossible.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Since it is of the nature of the memory to preserve the species of those things which are not actually apprehended, we must first of all consider whether the intelligible species can thus be preserved in the intellect: because Avicenna held that this was impossible.

column2: For he admitted that this could happen in the sensitive part, as to some powers, inasmuch as they are acts of corporeal organs, in which certain species may be preserved apart from actual apprehension.
column3: For he admitted that this could happen in the sensitive part, as to some powers, inasmuch as they are acts of corporeal organs, in which certain species may be preserved apart from actual apprehension.

column2: But in the intellect, which has no corporeal organ, nothing but what is intelligible exists.
column3: But in the intellect, which has no corporeal organ, nothing but what is intelligible exists.

column2: Wherefore every thing of which the likeness exists in the intellect must be actually understood.
column3: Wherefore every thing of which the likeness exists in the intellect must be actually understood.

column2: Thus, therefore, according to him, as soon as we cease to understand something actually, the species of that thing ceases to be in our intellect, and if we wish to understand that thing anew, we must turn to the active intellect, which he held to be a separate substance, in order that the intelligible species may thence flow again into our passive intellect.
column3: Thus, therefore, according to him, as soon as we cease to understand something actually, the species of that thing ceases to be in our intellect, and if we wish to understand that thing anew, we must turn to the active intellect, which he held to be a separate substance, in order that the intelligible species may thence flow again into our passive intellect.

column2: And from the practice and habit of turning to the active intellect there is formed, according to him, a certain aptitude in the passive intellect for turning to the active intellect; which aptitude he calls the habit of knowledge.
column3: And from the practice and habit of turning to the active intellect there is formed, according to him, a certain aptitude in the passive intellect for turning to the active intellect; which aptitude he calls the habit of knowledge.

column2: According, therefore, to this supposition, nothing is preserved in the intellectual part that is not actually understood: wherefore it would not be possible to admit memory in the intellectual part.
column3: According, therefore, to this supposition, nothing is preserved in the intellectual part that is not actually understood: wherefore it would not be possible to admit memory in the intellectual part.

column2: But this opinion is clearly opposed to the teaching of Aristotle. For he says (De Anima iii, 4) that, when the passive intellect "is identified with each thing as knowing it, it is said to be in act," and that "this happens when it can operate of itself.
column3: But this opinion is clearly opposed to the teaching of Aristotle. For he says (De Anima iii, four) that, when the passive intellect "is identified with each thing as knowing it, it is said to be in act," and that "this happens when it can operate of itself.

column2: And, even then, it is in potentiality, but not in the same way as before learning and discovering." Now, the passive intellect is said to be each thing, inasmuch as it receives the intelligible species of each thing.
column3: And, even then, it is in potentiality, but not in the same way as before learning and discovering." Now, the passive intellect is said to be each thing, inasmuch as it receives the intelligible species of each thing.

column2: To the fact, therefore, that it receives the species of intelligible things it owes its being able to operate when it wills, but not so that it be always operating: for even then is it in potentiality in a certain sense, though otherwise than before the act of understanding--namely, in the sense that whoever has habitual knowledge is in potentiality to actual consideration.
column3: To the fact, therefore, that it receives the species of intelligible things it owes its being able to operate when it wills, but not so that it be always operating: for even then is it in potentiality in a certain sense, though otherwise than before the act of understanding-namely, in the sense that whoever has habitual knowledge is in potentiality to actual consideration.

column2: The foregoing opinion is also opposed to reason.
column3: The foregoing opinion is also opposed to reason.

column2: For what is received into something is received according to the conditions of the recipient.
column3: For what is received into something is received according to the conditions of the recipient.

column2: But the intellect is of a more stable nature, and is more immovable than corporeal nature.
column3: But the intellect is of a more stable nature, and is more immovable than corporeal nature.

column2: If, therefore, corporeal matter holds the forms which it receives, not only while it actually does something through them, but also after ceasing to act through them, much more cogent reason is there for the intellect to receive the species unchangeably and lastingly, whether it receive them from things sensible, or derive them from some superior intellect.
column3: If, therefore, corporeal matter holds the forms which it receives, not only while it actually does something through them, but also after ceasing to act through them, much more cogent reason is there for the intellect to receive the species unchangeably and lastingly, whether it receive them from things sensible, or derive them from some superior intellect.

column2: Thus, therefore, if we take memory only for the power of retaining species, we must say that it is in the intellectual part.
column3: Thus, therefore, if we take memory only for the power of retaining species, we must say that it is in the intellectual part.

column2: But if in the notion of memory we include its object as something past, then the memory is not in the intellectual, but only in the sensitive part, which apprehends individual things.
column3: But if in the notion of memory we include its object as something past, then the memory is not in the intellectual, but only in the sensitive part, which apprehends individual things.

column2: For past, as past, since it signifies being under a condition of fixed time, is something individual.
column3: For past, as past, since it signifies being under a condition of fixed time, is something individual.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Memory, if considered as retentive of species, is not common to us and other animals.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Memory, if considered as retentive of species, is not common to us and other animals.

column2: For species are not retained in the sensitive part of the soul only, but rather in the body and soul united: since the memorative power is the act of some organ.
column3: For species are not retained in the sensitive part of the soul only, but rather in the body and soul united: since the memorative power is the act of some organ.

column2: But the intellect in itself is retentive of species, without the association of any corporeal organ.
column3: But the intellect in itself is retentive of species, without the association of any corporeal organ.

column2: Wherefore the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, 4) that "the soul is the seat of the species, not the whole soul, but the intellect."
column3: Wherefore the Philosopher says (De Anima iii, four) that "the soul is the seat of the species, not the whole soul, but the intellect."

column2: Reply Obj. 2: The condition of past may be referred to two things--namely, to the object which is known, and to the act of knowledge.
column3: Reply o b j. two: The condition of past may be referred to two things-namely, to the object which is known, and to the act of knowledge.

column2: These two are found together in the sensitive part, which apprehends something from the fact of its being immuted by a present sensible: wherefore at the same time an animal remembers to have sensed before in the past, and to have sensed some past sensible thing.
column3: These two are found together in the sensitive part, which apprehends something from the fact of its being immuted by a present sensible: wherefore at the same time an animal remembers to have sensed before in the past, and to have sensed some past sensible thing.

column2: But as concerns the intellectual part, the past is accidental, and is not in itself a part of the object of the intellect.
column3: But as concerns the intellectual part, the past is accidental, and is not in itself a part of the object of the intellect.

column2: For the intellect understands man, as man: and to man, as man, it is accidental that he exist in the present, past, or future.
column3: For the intellect understands man, as man: and to man, as man, it is accidental that he exist in the present, past, or future.

column2: But on the part of the act, the condition of past, even as such, may be understood to be in the intellect, as well as in the senses.
column3: But on the part of the act, the condition of past, even as such, may be understood to be in the intellect, as well as in the senses.

column2: Because our soul's act of understanding is an individual act, existing in this or that time, inasmuch as a man is said to understand now, or yesterday, or tomorrow.
column3: Because our soul's act of understanding is an individual act, existing in this or that time, inasmuch as a man is said to understand now, or yesterday, or tomorrow.

column2: And this is not incompatible with the intellectual nature: for such an act of understanding, though something individual, is yet an immaterial act, as we have said above of the intellect (Q.
column3: And this is not incompatible with the intellectual nature: for such an act of understanding, though something individual, is yet an immaterial act, as we have said above of the intellect (Q.

column2: 76, A. 1); and therefore, as the intellect understands itself, though it be itself an individual intellect, so also it understands its act of understanding, which is an individual act, in the past, present, or future.
column3: seventy six, a one); and therefore, as the intellect understands itself, though it be itself an individual intellect, so also it understands its act of understanding, which is an individual act, in the past, present, or future.

column2: In this way, then, the notion of memory, in as far as it regards past events, is preserved in the intellect, forasmuch as it understands that it previously understood: but not in the sense that it understands the past as something "here" and "now."
column3: In this way, then, the notion of memory, in as far as it regards past events, is preserved in the intellect, forasmuch as it understands that it previously understood: but not in the sense that it understands the past as something "here" and "now."

column2: Reply Obj. 3: The intelligible species is sometimes in the intellect only in potentiality, and then the intellect is said to be in potentiality.
column3: Reply o b j. three: The intelligible species is sometimes in the intellect only in potentiality, and then the intellect is said to be in potentiality.

column2: Sometimes the intelligible species is in the intellect as regards the ultimate completion of the act, and then it understands in act.
column3: Sometimes the intelligible species is in the intellect as regards the ultimate completion of the act, and then it understands in act.

column2: And sometimes the intelligible species is in a middle state, between potentiality and act: and then we have habitual knowledge.
column3: And sometimes the intelligible species is in a middle state, between potentiality and act: and then we have habitual knowledge.

column2: In this way the intellect retains the species, even when it does not understand in act. _______________________
column3: In this way the intellect retains the species, even when it does not understand in act. , blank ,
